  "article_text": [
    "the binomial edge ideal of a graph was introduced in @xcite and @xcite .",
    "let @xmath1 be a finite simple graph with vertex set @xmath2 $ ] and edge set @xmath3 and let @xmath4 $ ] be the polynomial ring over a field @xmath5 .",
    "then the * binomial edge ideal * of @xmath1 in @xmath6 , denoted by @xmath7 , is generated by binomials @xmath8 , where @xmath9 and @xmath10 .",
    "one could see this ideal as an ideal generated by a collection of 2-minors of a @xmath11-matrix whose entries are all indeterminates .",
    "many of the algebraic properties of such ideals were studied in @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite and @xcite . in @xcite",
    ", the authors determined all graphs whose binomial edge ideal have a grbner basis with respect to the lexicographic order induced by @xmath12 , and called this class of graphs , * closed graphs*. there are also some combinatorial descriptions for these graphs . in @xcite , the authors introduced a generalization of the binomial edge ideal of a graph and some properties of this ideal were studied in @xcite and @xcite .    in this paper , we characterize all binomial edge ideals with pure resolutions .",
    "we also try to compute the linear strand of binomial edge ideals .",
    "we introduce a new method of switching for graphs which preserves many algebraic invariants of the binomial edge ideals .",
    "this paper is organized as follows . in section  [ binomial edge ideals with pure resolutions ]",
    ", we classify all graphs such that their binomial edge ideals have pure resolutions , which generalizes the result of schenzel and zafar who studied complete bipartite graphs . in section  [ free cut edge switching and linear strand of binomial edge ideals ]",
    ", we introduce a new switching method for graphs , where the graded betti numbers , regularity and projective dimension of binomial edge ideals are invariant under it . using that",
    ", we compute the graded betti numbers of some classes of graphs , generalizing some of the results of zahid and zafar in @xcite .",
    "also , we compute the linear strand of binomial edge ideals of some classes of graphs and pose a formula with respect to graphical terms as a conjecture , for an arbitrary graph .",
    "in this section , we investigate about pure resolutions of binomial edge ideals .",
    "let @xmath13 be a homogeneous ideal of @xmath6 whose generators all have degree @xmath14 .",
    "then @xmath13 has a * @xmath14-pure resolution * ( or pure resolution ) if its minimal graded free resolution can be written in the form @xmath15 where @xmath16 .",
    "in addition , we say that @xmath13 has a * @xmath14-linear resolution * ( or linear resolution ) if for all @xmath17 , @xmath18 for all @xmath19 . in @xcite and @xcite , all binomial edge ideals with linear resolution",
    "are characterized .",
    "[ linear ] ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  2.1 ) let @xmath1 be graph . then @xmath7 has a linear resolution if and only if @xmath1 is a complete graph",
    ".    a similar question could be asked about pure resolutions .",
    "indeed , characterizing all binomial edge ideals which has pure resolutions with respect to combinatorial terms would be interesting too .",
    "on the other hand , pure resolutions are important from the boij - sderberg theory s point of view , in which pure resolutions can be used as building blocks in order to obtain any betti diagram .",
    "the following theorem which characterizes all graphs whose binomial edge ideals have pure resolutions , is the main theorem of this section .    [ pure ]",
    "let @xmath1 be a graph without any isolated vertices .",
    "then @xmath7 has a pure resolution if and only if @xmath1 is a + _ ( a ) _ complete graph , or + _ ( b ) _ complete bipartite graph , or + _ ( c ) _ disjoint union of some paths .    to prove the above theorem , we need some facts which are mentioned in the following .",
    "let @xmath1 and @xmath20 be two graphs .",
    "then we say that @xmath1 is @xmath20-free , if it does not have any induced subgraphs isomorphic to the graph @xmath20 . here , by @xmath21 , @xmath22 , @xmath23 and @xmath24 , for some @xmath25 with @xmath26 , we mean the cycle , complete graph , path and complete bipartite graph , on @xmath27 vertices , respectively . also , by @xmath28 , we mean the induced subgraph of a graph @xmath1 on @xmath2\\setminus v$ ] .",
    "[ induced ] ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  8) let @xmath1 be a graph and @xmath20 an induced subgraph of @xmath1 .",
    "then we have @xmath29 , for all @xmath30 .",
    "in particular , if @xmath7 has a pure resolution , then @xmath31 does too .",
    "[ special graphs ] _",
    "suppose that we label the vertices of @xmath23 such that its edges are of the form @xmath32 , for all @xmath33 .",
    "then , since @xmath23 is a closed graph , we have @xmath34 is minimally generated by @xmath35 , which is a regular sequence of monomials .",
    "it follows that the generators of @xmath36 form a regular sequence as well .",
    "therefore , the koszul complex resolves @xmath37 .",
    "consequently , @xmath37 has a pure resolution , and @xmath38 , if @xmath39 , and @xmath40 , otherwise .",

    ". then @xmath52 has a pure resolution if and only if @xmath53 , @xmath54 , and @xmath55 , for all @xmath30 .",

    "thus , we have @xmath59 for all @xmath30",
    ".    _ proof of theorem  [ pure ] .",
    "_ by theorem  [ linear ] , @xmath60 has a linear resolution , and hence a pure resolution . by remark  [ special graphs ]",
    ", @xmath36 has also a pure resolution . so that , if @xmath1 is the disjoint union of some paths , say @xmath61 , then the minimal graded free resolution of @xmath62 is the tensor product of the minimal graded free resolutions of @xmath63 s , and hence it is clearly pure . if @xmath1 is a complete bipartite graph , then by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  5.3 ) , @xmath64 has a pure resolution .",
    "conversely , suppose that @xmath7 has a pure resolution .",
    "if it also has a linear resolution , then by theorem  [ linear ] , @xmath1 is complete .",
    "so , suppose that @xmath7 has a pure and non - linear resolution .",
    "thus , @xmath1 is a non - complete graph .",

    "thus , @xmath1 is a @xmath67-free graph , by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  2.2 ) .",
    "if @xmath1 has an induced graph isomorphic to @xmath68 , for @xmath69 , then @xmath7 does not have any pure resolutions , by proposition  [ induced ] and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary  3.8 ) .",
    "thus , we have that @xmath1 is @xmath68-free , for all @xmath70 . in particular , @xmath1 does not contain any induced odd cycles and hence any odd cycles , which yields that @xmath1 is a bipartite graph .",
    "let @xmath71 and @xmath72 be the bipartition of the vertex set of @xmath1 . if @xmath1 is a tree , then it is @xmath23 , or @xmath73 , or has an induced subgraph isomorphic the graph shown in figure  [ g_2 ] .",
    "but , in the latter case , @xmath7 does not have any pure resolution , by remark  [ special graphs ] . now , suppose that @xmath1 has at least one induced cycle which has to be of length @xmath74 .",
    "so , we have @xmath75 .",

    "let @xmath80 be an induced cycle of @xmath1 on the vertices @xmath81 , where @xmath82 and @xmath83 .",
    "note that @xmath28 is a bipartite graph for which @xmath84 has a pure resolution , by proposition  [ induced ] , since @xmath28 is an induced subgraph of @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath20 be the graph depicted in figure  [ square ] .",
    "note that , @xmath28 is connected , because by replacing @xmath85 by @xmath86 in each path between two vertices @xmath87 and @xmath88 of @xmath1 which contains @xmath85 , one obtains a path between @xmath87 and @xmath88 in @xmath28 , as otherwise , @xmath1 is not @xmath20-free , a contradiction by remark  [ special graphs ] . if @xmath28 is a tree , then @xmath28 is @xmath89 or @xmath90 .",
    "if @xmath28 is @xmath89 , then , clearly , @xmath1 has an induced subgraph isomorphic to @xmath20 , containing @xmath80 , which is a contradiction , by remark  [ special graphs ] . if @xmath28 is @xmath90 , then @xmath91 .",
    "so that , if @xmath1 is not complete bipartite , in this case , then there is a vertex @xmath87 in @xmath72 which is not adjacent to @xmath85 .",
    "therefore , the induced subgraph of @xmath1 on @xmath92 is isomorphic to @xmath20 , a contradiction .",
    "now , assume that @xmath28 is not a tree and contains an induced cycle of length @xmath74 .",
    "thus , by the induction hypothesis , we have that @xmath28 is a complete bipartite graph .",
    "so that @xmath1 is also complete bipartite , because otherwise , there is a vertex @xmath93 which is not adjacent to @xmath85 and consequently , the induced subgraph on @xmath94 is isomorphic to @xmath20 , a contradiction , since @xmath7 has a pure resolution .",
    "now , assume that @xmath1 is a disconnected graph with connected components @xmath95 , where @xmath96 . by proposition  [ induced ]",
    ", @xmath97 has a pure resolution , for all @xmath98 .",
    "hence , @xmath99 is a path , or a complete graph , or a complete bipartite graph , for all @xmath98 , by the above discussion . on the other hand",
    ", @xmath100 has also a pure resolution , for all @xmath101 , again by proposition  [ induced ] .",
    "now , it suffices to apply lemma  [ lemma ] for @xmath97 and @xmath102 .",
    "therefore , all connected components of @xmath1 are paths , by theorem  [ linear ] , remark  [ special graphs ] , and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  5.3 ) .",
    "in this section , we introduce a new switching for graphs and study some algebraic invariants of binomial edge ideals through this switching . also , we study the linear strand of binomial edge ideals via graphical terms .",
    "let @xmath1 be a graph on @xmath2 $ ] and @xmath85 a vertex of it . if @xmath104 is an edge of @xmath1 , then two vertices @xmath85 and @xmath86 are called the endpoints of @xmath105 . if @xmath106 is a set of edges of @xmath1 , then by @xmath107 , we mean the graph on the same vertex set as @xmath1 in which the edges @xmath108 are omitted . to simplify our notation",
    ", we write @xmath109 , instead of @xmath110 .",
    "an edge @xmath105 of @xmath1 whose deletion from the graph , yields a graph with more connected components than @xmath1 , is called a * cut edge * of @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath111 be the clique complex of @xmath1 , the simplicial complex whose facets are the vertex sets of the maximal cliques of @xmath1 .",
    "we say that a vertex of @xmath1 is a * free vertex * , if it is a free vertex of @xmath111 , i.e. it is contained in only one facet of @xmath111 .",
    "let @xmath1 be a graph and @xmath105 a cut edge of @xmath1 such that its endpoints are the free vertices of the graph @xmath109 .",
    "then , we call @xmath105 , a * free cut edge * of @xmath1 .",
    "suppose that @xmath106 is the set of all free cut edges of @xmath1 .",
    "then , we call the graph @xmath112 , the * reduced graph * of @xmath1 , and denote it by @xmath113 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition  3.3 ) ) .",
    "set @xmath114 , if @xmath1 does not have any free cut edges .",
    "as in @xcite , if @xmath115 are two vertices of a graph @xmath116 and @xmath104 is not an edge of @xmath1 , then @xmath117 is defined to be the graph on the vertex set @xmath118 , and the edge set @xmath119 .",
    "the set of all neighbors ( i.e. adjacent vertices ) of the vertex @xmath85 in @xmath1 , is denoted by @xmath120 . by @xmath121 , we mean the binomial @xmath8 , in which @xmath122 is an edge of @xmath1 .",
    "now , we recall the following propositions from @xcite .        motivated by proposition  [ colon2 ] , we introduce a new method of switching of graphs which is based on the existence of some free cut edges and free vertices in a graph .",
    "let @xmath115 be two vertices of @xmath1 .",
    "then , by @xmath130 , we mean the graph obtained from @xmath1 , by adding the edge @xmath104 to @xmath1 , where @xmath105 is not an edge of @xmath1 .",
    "[ switching ] _ let @xmath1 be a graph and @xmath105 be a free cut edge of @xmath1 .",
    "then , we say that @xmath131 is obtained from @xmath1 , by * `` free cut edge '' switching * , if @xmath132 is a free cut edge of @xmath133 .",
    "_    note that @xmath1 and @xmath133 are on the same vertex set , and also @xmath105 and @xmath132 could have a vertex in common .",
    "this switching is possible if and only if @xmath1 has at least a free cut edge and at least a free vertex .",
    "for example , one could do it on a forest and obtain again a forest .",
    "+ now , let us recall a criterion for checking the closedness of a graph due to cox and erskine in @xcite .",
    "they call a connected graph @xmath1 , _ narrow _ , if every vertex is distance at most one from every longest shortest path . here , the distance @xmath134 between two vertices @xmath115 of @xmath1 is the length of the shortest path connecting them ; the diameter @xmath135 of @xmath1 is the maximum distance between two vertices of @xmath1 , and a shortest path connecting two vertices @xmath85 and @xmath86 for which @xmath136 , is called a longest shortest path of @xmath1 .",
    "finally , in @xcite , it is shown that @xmath1 is closed if and only if it is chordal , claw - free and narrow .",
    "_ let @xmath1 be the graph depicted in figure  [ switching1 ] .",
    "the edge @xmath105 is a free cut edge and the vertex @xmath137 is a free vertex of @xmath109 .",
    "we can apply free cut edge switching to @xmath1 .",
    "we delete @xmath105 and join the free vertices @xmath115 of @xmath109 , by an edge @xmath132 to obtain the graph @xmath133 , shown in figure  [ switching2 ] .",
    "the edge @xmath132 is also a free cut edge of @xmath133 .",
    "note that , @xmath138 and @xmath139 .",
    "thus , obviously , @xmath1 and @xmath133 are non - isomorphic graphs , for instance , by the above criterion of cox and erskine , we have @xmath1 is non - closed and @xmath133 is closed . note",
    "that , @xmath140 is a longest shortest path of @xmath1 , and the distance of @xmath86 from @xmath141 is @xmath142 , which implies that @xmath1 is not narrow nd hence not closed . using the same criterion , one could easily see that @xmath133 is closed .",
    "but , as we see below , many properties of them coincide . _                    [ invariants ] _ the above proposition shows that the graded betti numbers , projective dimension and regularity of the binomial edge ideals of graphs are invariant under `` free cut edge '' switching .",
    "thus , through this operation , we might get some non - isomorphic graphs with different binomial edge ideals , whose minimal graded free resolutions are numerically the same .",
    "one could also ask similar questions about some other algebraic or combinatorial properties and invariants , through this switching .",
    "_    [ cut edge switching ] _ one may think of defining a more general method of switching , using `` cut edges '' instead of `` free cut edges '' .",
    "but , the properties mentioned in proposition  [ switching - betti ] are not valid in that case anymore .",
    "for example , consider @xmath1 to be the graph shown in figure  [ tree ] .",
    "the edge @xmath105 is a cut edge , which is not a free cut edge .",
    "if we delete the edge @xmath105 and add @xmath146 instead , we gain @xmath147 . as we showed in the previous section",
    ", @xmath148 has a pure resolution , but @xmath64 does not .",
    "_          now , we want to compute the exact values of some of these algebraic invariants of binomial edge ideals of some classes of graphs .",
    "+ let @xmath149 .",
    "a * lollipop * graph , denoted by @xmath150 , is a graph which is obtained from a complete graph @xmath151 and a path @xmath152 such that a vertex of @xmath151 and a leaf of @xmath152 are joined .",
    "figure  [ lollipop ] shows a lollipop graph @xmath150 .          a * k - handle lollipop * graph , denoted by @xmath153 , where @xmath149 and @xmath154 , is a graph obtained from a complete graph @xmath151 and @xmath155 paths of lengths @xmath156 , such that a leaf of each path is joined to a vertex of @xmath151 , respectively .",
    "one could easily see that @xmath153 is obtained by some consecutive `` free cut edge '' switchings , from @xmath150 , where @xmath157 .",
    "note that the order of @xmath156 is not important in the notation of @xmath153 .",
    "it is easy to see that @xmath150 is a closed graph , but @xmath153 might not be closed .",
    "figure  [ lollipop1 ] shows the lollipop graph @xmath158 , and figure  [ lollipop2 ] shows the @xmath142-handle lollipop graph @xmath159 , which is obtained by a `` free cut edge '' switching from @xmath158 .",
    "one of the benefits of proposition  [ switching - betti ] is that while we study such algebraic invariants , we can restrict the problem to a much simpler case .",
    "the following proposition could be a good example of this fact .",
    "there , we turn the problem to one for a simple closed graph .",
    "note that the result of @xcite on the class @xmath160 of graphs is a special case of the following .      as mentioned above ,",

    "_    now , we focus on the linear strand of the binomial edge ideals .",
    "the following theorem determines the linear strand of the binomial edge ideal of a class of graphs , which is closed under `` free cut edge '' switching , that is if @xmath1 belongs to this class , then every ( possible ) `` free cut edge '' switching of @xmath1 also is in this class .",
    "it generalizes corollary  [ linear strand - lollipop ] .",

    "so , by an easy computation , we have @xmath204 . by assumption ,",

    "* acknowledgments : * the authors would like to thank the referee for suggesting lemma  [ lemma ] which shortened the original proof of the main theorem of the paper , and also for his or her other valuable comments .",
    "moreover , the authors would like to thank to the institute for research in fundamental sciences ( ipm ) for financial support .",
    "the research of the first author was in part supported by a grant from ipm ( no .",
    "93050220 ) ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we characterize all graphs whose binomial edge ideals have pure resolutions . moreover </S>",
    "<S> , we introduce a new switching of graphs which does not change some algebraic invariants of graphs , and using this , we study the linear strand of the binomial edge ideals for some classes of graphs . also , we pose a conjecture on the linear strand of such ideals for every graph .    </S>",
    "<S> department of pure mathematics , faculty of mathematics and computer science , amirkabir university of technology ( tehran polytechnic ) , 424 , hafez ave . , </S>",
    "<S> tehran 15914 , iran , and school of mathematics , institute for research in fundamental sciences ( ipm ) , p.o . </S>",
    "<S> box 19395 - 5746 , tehran , iran.]dkiani@aut.ac.ir , dkiani7@gmail.com , @xmath0sarasaeedi@aut.ac.ir ] </S>"
  ]
}
